SEARCH
Package server

Class MyHTTPServer

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Thread
server.MyHTTPServer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Runnable, HTTPServer
public class MyHTTPServer extends Thread implements HTTPServer
MyHTTPServer is a concrete implementation of the HTTPServer interface. It provides a multi-threaded HTTP server that can handle GET, POST, and DELETE requests by routing them to registered servlets based on URI patterns.

The server uses a thread pool to handle concurrent requests efficiently and supports servlet registration/removal at runtime. It performs longest-prefix matching for URI routing and includes comprehensive error handling and logging capabilities.

Example usage:

 
 MyHTTPServer server = new MyHTTPServer(8080, 10);
 server.addServlet("GET", "/api", new ApiServlet());
 server.start();
Since:
1.0
Version:
1.0
Author:
Almog Sharoni Yuval Harary

  • Constructor Details

    • MyHTTPServer

      public MyHTTPServer(int port, int nThreads)
      Constructs a new MyHTTPServer instance with the specified port and thread pool size.
      Parameters:
      port - the port number on which the server should listen (1-65535)
      nThreads - the number of threads in the thread pool for handling requests
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if port is not in valid range (1-65535) or nThreads is negative

  • Method Details

    • addServlet

      public void addServlet(String httpCommand, String uri, servlets.Servlet s)
      Registers a servlet to handle HTTP requests for a specific command and URI pattern. The servlet will be called when incoming requests match both the HTTP method and URI pattern.
      Specified by:
      addServlet in interface HTTPServer
      Parameters:
      httpCommand - the HTTP method this servlet should handle ("GET", "POST", or "DELETE")
      uri - the URI pattern that this servlet should handle (e.g., "/api", "/upload")
      s - the servlet instance that will process matching requests
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if httpCommand is not "GET", "POST", or "DELETE"
      NullPointerException - if any parameter is null

    • removeServlet

      public void removeServlet(String httpCommand, String uri)
      Removes a previously registered servlet for the specified HTTP command and URI pattern.
      Specified by:
      removeServlet in interface HTTPServer
      Parameters:
      httpCommand - the HTTP method of the servlet to remove ("GET", "POST", or "DELETE")
      uri - the URI pattern of the servlet to remove
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if httpCommand is not "GET", "POST", or "DELETE"
      NullPointerException - if any parameter is null

    • start

      public void start()
      Starts the HTTP server and begins listening for incoming connections. This method starts the server thread which initializes the server socket and thread pool.

      This method is non-blocking and returns immediately after starting the server thread. The actual server operations are performed in the run() method on a separate thread.

      Specified by:
      start in interface HTTPServer
      Overrides:
      start in class Thread
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the server is already running
      RuntimeException - if the server fails to start due to port conflicts or other issues
      See Also:
      • run()

    • run

      public void run()
      Starts the HTTP server and begins listening for incoming connections. This method creates a server socket, initializes the thread pool, and enters the main server loop to accept and handle client connections.

      The server runs in its own thread and performs the following:

      • Sets up error logging to server_error.log
      • Creates a ServerSocket on the specified port
      • Initializes the thread pool with the specified number of threads
      • Accepts incoming connections and delegates them to worker threads

      This method implements the Runnable interface and should be called by starting the server thread or calling start() which internally calls this method.

      Specified by:
      run in interface Runnable
      Overrides:
      run in class Thread
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if the server fails to start due to port conflicts or I/O errors
      See Also:
      • start()

    • close

      public void close()
      Gracefully shuts down the HTTP server and releases all associated resources. This method performs the following cleanup operations:
      • Closes the server socket to stop accepting new connections
      • Shuts down the thread pool and waits for existing tasks to complete
      • Closes all registered servlets to release their resources

      The method waits up to 5 seconds for the thread pool to terminate gracefully before forcing shutdown.

      Specified by:
      close in interface HTTPServer
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if an error occurs during server shutdown
